content:
Yes, you can convert the date string to epoch time, and then subtract the desired offset (in this case, 5 hours for GMT-5) to get the correct date and time in the desired time zone.

Here's an example formula that takes the date string in cell B2 and converts it to epoch time, then subtracts 5 hours (for GMT-5) to get the desired time:
```scss
=TEXT(((B2-DATE(1899,12,30))*86400-(5*3600))/86400+DATE(1899,12,30),"MM/DD/YYYY hh:mm:ss AM/PM")
```
This formula will take the date string in cell B2, convert it to epoch time in GMT, subtract 5 hours (for GMT-5), and then convert it back to a date string in the format `MM/DD/YYYY hh:mm:ss AM/PM`. The result should be:
```
01/17/2023 12:26:31 PM
```
